skill.name: using-git-worktrees
skill.description: Use when starting feature work that needs isolation from current workspace or before executing implementation plans - creates isolated git worktrees with smart directory selection and safety verification

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown guidance for setting up git worktrees. No executable code, no file system writes, no network access, no environment variable reads. The document describes safe git operations that are performed by the AI agent following the documented workflow.

content.value_statement: Working on multiple features simultaneously requires constant branch switching, which disrupts context and slows progress. This skill creates isolated git worktrees that let you work on separate branches in parallel directories without switching, while automatically verifying gitignore safety and running clean test baselines.
actual_capabilities: Create isolated git worktrees with automatic directory detection
Verify worktree directories are properly gitignored before creation
Auto-detect project type and run appropriate setup commands
Run test baselines to confirm clean starting state
Follow project conventions from CLAUDE.md or prompt user for preference
limitations: Requires git repository with write access
Cannot create worktrees on remote filesystems without SSH access
Global worktree location requires ~/.config/superpowers/worktrees directory creation
Test commands must be available in project PATH (npm, cargo, pytest, go)

use_cases.title: Parallel feature development
use_cases.description: Work on multiple features simultaneously without constant branch switching or stashing changes

use_cases.title: Test pull request changes
use_cases.description: Create isolated workspace to review PR changes with clean test baseline before merging

use_cases.title: Enforce workspace standards
use_cases.description: Standardize worktree locations and safety checks across team projects via CLAUDE.md conventions

prompt_templates.title: Basic worktree creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an isolated git worktree for a new feature branch called [feature-name] in the appropriate worktree directory.

prompt_templates.title: With CLAUDE.md preference
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a worktree for [feature-name] using the worktree directory specified in CLAUDE.md.

prompt_templates.title: Global location
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a worktree in the global location (~/.config/superpowers/worktrees/[project]/[branch]) for [feature-name].

prompt_templates.title: With cleanup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a worktree for [feature-name], verify tests pass, then clean up the worktree when finished.

output_examples.input: Create an isolated git worktree for the auth feature
output: Creating worktree: git worktree add .worktrees/auth -b feature/auth

best_practices: Always verify the worktree directory is gitignored before creating project-local worktrees to prevent accidental commits
Check CLAUDE.md for project-specific worktree conventions before asking the user for preference
Run test baselines immediately after setup to establish a clean state before making changes
anti_patterns: Skipping gitignore verification - worktree files may accidentally get committed to the repository
Proceeding with failing tests without asking - cannot distinguish new bugs from pre-existing issues
Hardcoding worktree directory locations - different projects may have different conventions

faq.question: Which platforms support git worktrees?
faq.answer: Git worktrees require Git 2.5 or later. Supported on Linux, macOS, and Windows with Git Bash, WSL, or PowerShell with git installed.

faq.question: How many worktrees can I create?
faq.answer: Git does not limit worktree count, but each requires disk space. Create as many as needed for your workflow.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing tools?
faq.answer: The skill auto-detects Node.js, Rust, Python, and Go projects. For other tools, manually run setup after worktree creation.

faq.question: Is my data safe in worktrees?
faq.answer: Worktrees are full git repositories. Code and files remain local. The skill verifies gitignore to prevent accidental commits.

faq.question: Worktree creation failed - what now?
faq.answer: Common causes: branch already exists, directory conflicts, or insufficient permissions. Check git error message and remove conflicting branches or directories.

faq.question: How does this differ from cloning the repo?
faq.answer: Worktrees share the .git directory with the main repo, reducing disk space. Commits sync automatically without pushing to remote.
